Title: Turkey: Country Guide
Content:
Exotic beaches, mystical cities, and arid deserts.

KWB's Highlights:
  • There are many synagogues including Chabad, mainly in Istanbul.
  • Two Jewish museums.
  • Six Kosher restaurants and 9 Kosher butchers, most of them in Istanbul.
  • Mt. Hararat where Noah's Ark was found.
  • Jewish museum.
  • Turkey is blessed with amazing hotels, not just 5 star, but all the way to 5 diamond.
  • Thermal baths.
  • Exotic & pristine beaches.
  • We want to know more! Let us know what we are missing!
More details:
  • Long ago, Turkey (aka the Ottoman Empire) conquered nations and managed its way to the Land of Israel. A magical country, with bazaars like Aladdin, with amazing flavours due to the quantity and quality of spices, fishes, and vegetables.
  • It is one of those countries that doesn't stop impressing visitors.
  • It is filled with history, natural resources, and places to go. From exotic beaches, mystical cities and arid deserts.
  • It has one of the most important sea passages in the world, the Bosphorus which divides the country in two, the Asian side and the European side.
  • People visit Turkey for tourism and business.
  • The capital is Ankara, but Istanbul is the most touristic city. Turkey also has what was the nest of Sephardic jewellery in the area, Edirne.
  • Five centuries ago, during the inquisition, the Sultan at that time, sent fleets to save Jews from the Spanish persecution and bring them to Turkey.
  • Now a days, even though the Turkish president has declared his hatred towards Israel and there have been couple of terrorist attack towards the community, there is still a safe place for Turkish jews. They live happy there, no one bothers them.  The native turk is friendly, passionate for hosting and knows that tourism is important. As Turkey is an Islamic country, please be aware of those around you and their culture.
Content_Tagline: Exotic beaches, mystical cities, and arid deserts.
KWB_Highlight:
There are many synagogues mainly in Istanbul.

Two Jewish museums.

Six Kosher restaurants and 9 Kosher butchers, most of them in Istanbul.

Mt. Hararat where Noah's Ark was found.

Jewish museum

Turkey is blessed with amazing hotels, not just 5 star, but all the way to 5 diamond.

Thermal baths.

Exotic & Pristine beaches.

We want to know more! Let us know what we are missing!
More Information::
Long ago, Turkey (aka the Ottoman Empire) conquered nations and managed its way to the Land of Israel. A magical country, with bazaars like Aladdin, with amazing flavours due to the quantity and quality of spices, fishes, and vegetables.
It is one of those countries that doesn't stop impressing visitors.
It is filled with history, natural resources, and places to go. From exotic beaches, mystical cities and arid deserts.
 It has one of the most important sea passages in the world, the Bosphorus which divides the country in two, the Asian side and the European side.
People visit Turkey for tourism and business.
The capital is Ankara, but Istanbul is the most touristic city. Turkey also has what was the nest of Sephardic jewellery in the area, Edirne.
Five centuries ago, during the inquisition, the Sultan at that time, sent fleets to save Jews from the Spanish persecution and bring them to Turkey.
Now a days, even though the Turkish president has declared his hatred towards Israel and there have been couple of terrorist attack towards the community, there is still a safe place for Turkish jews. They live happy there, no one bothers them.  The native turk is friendly, passionate for hosting and knows that tourism is important. As Turkey is an Islamic country, please be aware of those around you and their culture.

Title: Brazil Country Guide
Content:
Welcome to Brazil!

KWB Highlights:
  • The main jewish community lives in São Paulo in the neighborhoods of Higienopolis (where most Kosher Restaurants and Shuls are located) and Jadins/ Cerqueira César (near the main touristy streets and some restaurants and kosher shops).
  • Rio also has a sizable Jewish Community and best places to stay are Copacabana, Ipanema or Leblon - The main beaches in Rio, they’re all next to each other and there’s a Chabad in each place.
  • Chabad is also active in the following cities:  Belém, Belo Horizonte, Manaus, Recife, Salvador, Morro de São Paulo, Porto Alegre and more.
  • Use buskasher.com.br to search the foods that are kosher at any supermarket around Brazil, you’re able to search by category, brand or name. (There are  2 types of lists - the green list is for people who only eat Chalav Yisrael and Pas Yisrael and the Yellow list is for those who don’t only eat Chalav Yisrael and Pas Yisrael.)
São Paulo:
  •   There are around 11 kosher restaurants in São Paulo:
            The dairy restaurants are: Sushi Papaya, Miki Kosher, Mocha Bleu, Bero Pizza, Matok and Via Babush. The meaty restaurants are: Metzuyan, Nur, Kosher da Barros, Smoke Deli and Pinati. There’s also 2 ice cream shops - Trevisi and Le Botteghe di Leonardo (not everything is Chalav Yisroel (green list) on both shops. Ask them for the Kosher menu).
  • There’s 3 Kosher grocery stores and 1 supermarket:
All Kosher, Mazal Tov, Pardes and Urbanic Food Hall (also known as Super K)
  • Go to Kosher Delight for baked goods and basic grocery needs.
  • Many neighborhoods in Sao Paolo have an Eruv! Check here for updates.
  • You can get a full Shabbos Meal Kit from Delicious by Chaya. Whatsapp- +5511957610090 and instagram @deliciousbychaya. Get a free dessert if you mention @caughthebug.
Rio:
  • The kosher supermarket is located in CIB - Clube Israelita Brasileiro. They also have ready made meal options, you’d only need to heat it up.
  •  Shaqshuq - This kosher restaurant is located at the same place as the supermarket and they have meat and dairy options. They also offer free delivery for the neighborhoods of Copacabana, Ipanema and Leblon. (Be sure to check their opening hours before.)
  •  You can order food for Shabbos with Roger Najman - +5521988748457 a local chef.
  •  Boteco do Monte is a pub in the Monte Sinai Jewish Club in Tijuca - Open only on Sundays for lunch (meaty)
  •  There’s a kosher bakery from “Lar da Esperança” that  gives their profits to the local old age home. They only take orders but Beit Lubavitch Leblon has a small store where they sell some of their products.
Safety tips:
  • Brazil has a reputation for being a dangerous place however it’s still possible to enjoy the country and be safe. Try doing things like leaving your phone in your bag when walking on the streets (especially in Rio) to prevent pickpockets from stealing it, don’t walk through empty/dark roads at night and pay attention to your surroundings.
Antisemitism:
  • Brazilians in general are very religious and tolerant towards different religions.
Language:
  • Most Brazilians don’t speak English so be ready to use and abuse Google Translate.
  BDK  BRAZIL  (KOSHER  PRODUCTS)
  • Oficial Website of BDK BRAZIL

Title: Pushkar: City Guide
Content:
Pushkar is a very busy and diverse place. Walk in to the Chabad and feel the refreshing change of setting.

KWB’s Highlights:
  • For the updated and complete directory of kosher providers in India, CLICK HERE .
  • The city is vegetarian, meat is not allowed, including in Chabad.
  • There is a tourist tax (very inexpensive) when visiting the city.
  • When you visit the market, buy a wooden chess set, and bring your Tefilin with you. In under, an hour I was able to wrap Tefilin with 5 backpackers. If you've never done this before, now is a good time to start.
  • The city has a holy lake in the centre, and people come from all over the country to bathe in it.
  • People will offer you flowers to throw in the lake and ask for a donation.
  • We don't think that's something Jewish people should participate in.
  • There are shrines everywhere, including the side walk.
  • Shabbat there is an unforgettable experience.
  • See the hotels we recommend. Keep in mind there is nothing super fancy there.
  • For more information about kosher establishments, click here.

Title: Fly to Key West for Lunch (ad)
Content:
Fly you to Key West for lunch in a private airplane.

Are you in Miami but don't like the restaurants there? We feel your pain. That's why we will take you, and up to two friends, to Key West for lunch, and get you back in Miami in time for dinner.
  • Get there in style. Arrive in your own private single engine airplane.
  • Flight time is about 1.5 hours.
  • Fly with experienced pilots.
  • Cost: $900-$1300 total for up to 2 people, inclusive of fuel, pilot, landing fees.
  • Your plane will be a Cirrus SR22 or similar. The only plane of it's kind that features a parachute.
  • KWB will arrange for the passenger seating in the front to have a try at the controls for a few minutes.
  • Impress your shidduch date, celebrate your anniversary, or have a great time with friends.
  • Have lunch at Mam's Kosher Restaurant in Key West, explore the city and come back the same night.
  • Would you like to stay a few nights? We will arrange for the pilot to pick you up again for $800.
  • Heading to Tampa, Orlando, Tallahassee, or any other city in Florida, just let us know.
  • Subject to availability, weather, and other factors.

Title: Switzerland: Country Guide
Content:
Jewish history surrounded by awe-inspiring scenery.

KWB’s Highlights:
  • Jewish community in Switzerland is small but well organised and full of places where you can connect with the Jewish heritage.
  • Swiss people are not known for their sense of humor.
Shabbat in Switzerland? 
  • Le Jardin offers Challah available on order and Kosher meals can be order to any of Geneva's hotels.
  • In Geneva, EMS Les Marronniers cooks meal of Shabbos only by previous reservation. You can dine in or order to takeaway.
Kosher
  • Additionally, Olive Garden in Zurich and Restaurant Holbeinhof in Basel, are great options to dine in during the week.
  • More? Check our list of restaurants in Switzerland here.
What to do?
  • Geneva is an amazing option if you want to stay for several days some luxury hotels like Le Beau-Rivage offer Kosher meals upon request. However, they don't have a Kosher menu and meals are cooked in the kitchen with no confirmed supervision.
  • In this beautiful city you can visit Macom, Geneva’s principal Jewish community centre, which offers a sanctuary, a main Jewish library and Le Jardin Kosher restaurant.
  • Zurich is home to nearly half of Switzerland’s estimated 7,000 Jews, according to Europe for Visitors,  and it has been a center for Jewish culture for centuries, so that can be another stop in your itinerary.
  • If you are an adventurous traveller, take a hike, skii or climb great heights, such as the famous matterhorn, in the outstanding outdoor options Switzerland offers.
Share your travel notes with us so we can make this Country Guide better for everyone!

Title: Madrid Airport Kosher Tips
Content:
KWB Highlights:
  • You can request a Kosher meal in the Neptuno Lounge (AENA VIP Lounge) MAD Terminal 4S (Inside Security)
Fellow Kosher traveler Shimi Erenthal shared with us: "When I was there before Sukkos on the way to Israel, they had a variety of prepackaged salads and sandwiches sealed with a hechsher."  March 11, 2020
_listing_location: Madrid-Barajas Adolfo Suárez Airport (MAD), Av de la Hispanidad, s/n, 28042 Madrid, Spain

Title: Peru: Country Guide
Content:
Looking for an adventure? Then Peru is looking for you.

KWB's Highlights:
  • You are probably here for one reason: Machu Pichu.
  • The nearest large city to Machu Pichu is Cuszco.
  • The Chabad House in Cuszco is fully equipped with restaurants, bakery and everything that backpackers need. Check out their listing.
  • Be aware of the surroundings.
  • Best time to visit is from November to December which is summer-spring time there.
  • The capital is Lima.
  • Share your trip notes with us and help the next traveler!
Other details:
  • Over 3000 types of potatoes.
  • Peru has Bolivia on the south-east, Ecuador on the north-west, Colombia on the north and Brazil on the east. It is one of the countries where the Amazon forest, the largest forest on earth, rests. Thanks to this, the array of roots used by locals to cure illnesses has brought people to this area to detox in a very organic and natural way.
  • The Jewish community started to come from Europe, escaping WWII. It is a small community where everyone knows each other and are very helpful to each other. There are traces of Jews coming even before, at the time of the Spanish colonisation.
  • Several years ago, a group of native Peruvians claimed to be descendants from one of the Jewish tribes and for many years they were keeping torah-mitzvot.
  • The Israeli rabbinate sent rabbis to investigate the case and now a days there is a population of 3000+ Jewish native Peruvians who are living in Israel  and accepted as 100% Jewish, most of them are Orthodox.
  • There is the main Jewish community called Union Israelita de Peru (Israelite Union of Peru) and  two Chabad houses, one in Lima and one in Cusco.
  • Being Kosher in Peru can be a bit difficult, but not impossible. There is also a JCC called Hebraica and a Jewish school called Leon Pinelo. There is also a Kosher market where they prepare foods for takeaway/delivery.
Content_Tagline: Looking for an adventure? Then Peru is looking for you.

Title: Caribbean Country Guide
Content:
Welcome to the Caribbean!

Imagine you are ready, all packed to go on vacations. You choose the right place, the Caribbean, the right people: friends or family. But what about food? Will you pack your own food? or you can see our amazing guide so you can choose where to eat on your vacation. The Caribbean is a region of the Americas that comprises the Caribbean Sea, its surrounding coasts, and its islands (some of which lie within the Caribbean Sea and some of which lie on the edge of the Caribbean Sea where it borders the North Atlantic Ocean). The region lies southeast of the Gulf of Mexico and of the North American mainland, east of Central America, and north of South America.  

The Bahamas:

  • Kosher groceries, including meat, chicken and snacks on the Island can be found in the following link. 
Chabad of Nassau
  • Check their FAQ before visiting, there is great information there.
  • Located in the Cable Beach neighborhood which is a 30 Minute drive from the Atlantis and a 15-minute walk from the Baha Mar.
The Nassau Synagogue
  • Established in 1913.
  • Over one hundred years ago a group of Jewish farmers packed their meager possessions, left the shtetls of Eastern Europe and settled in Rensselaer County.
Shabbat services:
  • Shabbat services are led by members and the lively discussion of the weekly Torah portion is in English. This informal style is meant to encourage everyone to participate and develop a strong sense of community.
  • Following kiddush,  a lunch is served, prepared by the congregants in their Kosher, dairy-only kitchen.
  • On special occasions or in memory of a loved one’s yarzheit, members may sponsor elaborate luncheons.
  • You may contact them here.
 

Turks and Caicos:

Chabad of Turks and Caicos: 
  • Shabat Services and meals offered.
  • Kosher Takeout delivered to Hotel or Villa.
  • To contact them for any inquiries click here.
  • Basic US brand food is available at the IGA Grocery Store with many certified products.
  • Kosher wine can be found at the “Wine Cellar”.
  • You should have no problem with customs bringing in your own Kosher food.
 

Cuba:

Beth Shalom Temple (Havana, Cuba)

Hebrew community centre in Havana. Conservative.

KWB’s Highlights:
  • Temple Beth Shalom, built in 1952, is a synagogue located in the Vedado neighborhood of downtown Havana.
  • If you have more information we would be happy to update this page.
  • To understand why there is no official Chabad in Cuba, which is also related to this organization, check out this article.
  • There are two synagogues in town (a Sephardic one nearby and the Orthodox in the old town), this is the main community building and the largest congregation.
  • In 1981, much of the original building was sold to the state and was then turned into the Bertolt Brecht Cultural Center, including a theatre, a music venue, a gallery, and a bar.
  • Overall, the Jewish community in Cuba has enjoyed security and anti-Semitism has been minimal. In the years leading up to his death, Fidel Castro even attended the community’s Hanukka celebration. (source)
  • Chabad Friends of Cuba’s site has useful information, click here.
  • The synagogue is located 3 miles northwest of downtown Havana.
  • Check out this article (which conveniently doesn’t mention Alan Gross) about being Jewish in Cuba today.
 

Cayman Islands:

Chabad Cayman Jewish Community Center

KWB’s Highlights:
  • The Jewish community of the Cayman Islands started to emerge in the 1970’s as local Jews began to come together to study, worship, and support each other in the continuity of their Jewish heritage.
  • The Cayman Islands is a British Overseas territory in the Western Caribbean Sea. It is an ideal business jurisdiction; sophisticated, stable, and strategically located only one hour flight from Miami and 3.5 hours from New York City.
Shabbat:
  • You can enjoy an elegant Shabbat dinner with the Cayman Jewish Community. Meet Jews from all over the world, dine on traditional Shabbat delicacies, with flavours of the Caribbean, complemented by the words of Torah and good company.
  • Please note, that Shabbat meals at Chabad Cayman, are subject to availability: You will receive an email response within 24 hours after your request confirming availability.
  • The Chabad House is open to all, and do not charge guests. However, you are encouraged to contribute towards activities (a minimum of $72 per person) to help offset the high costs of importing Kosher foods to the island.
  • The most popular and developed area of Grand Cayman is Seven Mile Beach. It is widely known for its beauty, recently receiving the honour of “The Caribbean’s Best Beach”.
  • There are hundreds of options for lodgings along Seven Mile Beach. The Beit Hillel Chabad House is located at the southern end of Seven Mile Beach, right off West Bay Rd and a short walking distance from the many condos and hotels in the area.
  • Synagogue: Shabbat Minyan services Friday evenings 6:45 – 7:30 pm (Summer times). Followed by a light Kiddush and Oneg Shabbat social.
  • Shabbat morning services 10:30 am – 12:00 pm. Followed by a Cholent Kiddush. They have a daily Minyan during Yeshiva week (late January) and other times throughout the year.
  • The Chabad Cayman Jewish Community Center at 7 Mile Shops is open for daily Shacharis prayers.

Title: Chile Country Guide
Content:
Welcome to Chile!

KWB Highlights:
  • There are about 4 active orthodox synagogues in Santiago and a Chabad House for backpackers in the the south (Pucon) open during the season.
  • Chabad has an amazing sit down Shabbat day Kiddush.
  • There is an extensive Kosher products list that is available on the Aish website.
In addition to the restaurants that we list, you might find the following providers useful:
  • More places to visit in Chile, here.
  • Click here to see the list of products.
Credit is owed to Chilekosher.cl for the information.

Title: Kyoto: City Guide
Content:
This listing will help you save hours in planning your trip to Kyoto.

KWB’s Highlights:
  • KWB's staff visited (in 2016) the unofficial Chabad in Kyoto. It's run by yeshiva students and they will prepare food for you to takeaway or for groups.
  • There are two Chabad Houses in Kyoto, one official, and one "unofficial."
  • There are many things to do in Kyoto, even if you will not visit temples.
  • This page will save you a lot of time planning your trip and sorting what is good, and what is appropriate for Kosher travelers.
  • We know there is something we missed! Let us know!
KYOTO Gion Corner:
  • Higashiyama District: A visit to Gion is best combined with a stroll through the nearby Higashiyama District, between Yasaka Shrine and Kiyomizudera. This area has more preserved streets and traditional shops selling all kinds of local foods, crafts and souvenirs.
  • Kyoto was the capital of Japan for centuries. Visit the imperial palace.
  • There are so many different things to see in Kyoto. We hope to expand this section soon. Can you help?
ARASHIYAMA
  • Do not miss Arashiyama. It's a day trip that cannot be missed right outside Kyoto. Choose a day with good weather. You get there by subway or bus. Very easy.
  • Okochi-Sanso Villa: One of the top sights in Kyoto. It rivals any of the city’s imperial properties, and you don’t need reservations to enter.
  • Bamboo forest and the bridge: You can access it directly from the main street of Arashiyama, a little to the north of the entrance to Tenryu-ji Temple, but it’s best paired with a visit to that temple (exit the north gate, take a left and you’ll be in the grove in no time). There’s just one main path through the grove, which leads slowly uphill. Once you get to the top of the hill, the entrance to the sublime Okochi-Sanso Villa is right in front of you (go in, you won’t regret it).
  • Togetsukyo Bridge (15 minutes): Cross the Togetsukyo Bridge and spend a few minutes viewing the bridge. Some of the best views are from downstream of the bridge.
  • Bamboo Groves (30 minutes): From Tenryuji walk to Arashiyama Station and rent a bicycle, then head into the bamboo groves behind Tenryuji Temple. Turn right as you get to the entrance of Okochi Sanso and continue towards Jojakkoji.
  • Saga-Toriimoto Preserved Street (45 minutes): Continue along the main road until you get to Saga-Toriimoto Preserved Street, a historic street lined by traditional townhouses (machiya). Explore the shops and restaurants along the way. This may be a good place to have lunch.
Content_Tagline: This listing will help you save hours in planning your trip to Kyoto.

Title: Country Guide Hawaii
Content:
Welcome to Hawaii Country Guide

Hawaii is full of diversity and community, who is working to create a community among Hawaiian Jews of all affiliations, to serve as a place for Hawaiian Jews to gather and commune.

  • In Hawaii you can find few kosher restaurants which some are:
            Oahu Kosher is located at the following address, 1670 Makaloa St, Honolulu, HI 96814, USA             Chabad of Hawaii located at the following address, 410 Atkinson Dr, Honolulu, HI 96814, USA.
  • You can find the following synagogues in Hawaii:
Temple Emanu-El  located at the following address 2550 HI-61, Honolulu, HI 96817.            Congregation Sof Ma'arav located at the following address 2500 HI-61, Honolulu, HI 96817            Aloha Jewish Chapel located at the following address Makalapa Gate, Bldg 514, Pearl Harbor Naval Base, Box 47, Pearl Harbor, HI 96860            Chabad of Hawaii located at the following address 2241 Kapiolani Blvd, Honolulu, HI 96826            Kona Beth Shalom located at the following address 75-1048 Henry St, Kailua-Kona, HI 96740

Title: Jaipur: City Guide
Content:
Rajasthan's pink city. Unreal.

KWB’s Highlights:
  • For the updated and complete directory of kosher providers in India, CLICK HERE .
  • We loved the Pink City.
  • Hotels we recommend: click here.
  • No Kosher food locally.
  • If you stay in an upscale. Hotel, bring a pan, and ask politely, you might be able to do some cooking in their kitchen.
Don't miss:

Title: Quick Guide to Eating Kosher in Disney World Parks
Content:
General information on Kosher food at the Disney Parks and tips to enjoying experience more.

KWB's Highlights:
  • Disney allows you to bring food, drinks snacks without any hassle.
  • The only rule is no loose ice.
  • Some Disney restaurants offer ready to go (without reservation meals), while others require advanced reservation.
  • Overpriced and not tasty, airplane style meals.
  • We recommend skipping this option and bring your own sandwiches instead. But some travelers might like the convenience.
Kosher Dining at Walt Disney World Parks
  • You can pre-order kosher meals at most Walt Disney World table service restaurants that accept reservations.
  • Typically kid style menu include: Hamburgers, hotdogs, macaroni & cheese.
  • Other options for adults, such as Matze Ball soup, garden salad, baked salmon, brisket and beef.
  • When we called the cost seems to be $62 per adult and $37 per child.
  • Under the OU Hashgacha.
  • The key is to call (407) WDW-DINE or (407) 939-3463 at least 24 hours in advance.
  • A prepayment is required to guarantee dining reservations.
  • For a memorable and uniquely Disney experience, Kosher Character Dining and Dinner Shows can be arranged.
  • Character Dining means that Disney characters, such as Cinderella or Winnie the Pooh, make rounds in the restaurant in which you are eating, stop at your table to say hello, and take photos together with you.
  List of Disney Park Restaurants that usually stock (no need to pre-order) ready to go kosher meals:
  • Animal Kingdom: Satu'li Canteen (in the new Pandora Land)
  • Hollywood Studios: ABC Commissary
  • Epcot Center: Liberty Inn - American Adventure, and at the Electric Umbrella
  • Magic Kingdom: Cosmic Ray's Starlight Café - Tomorrowland
  • All Star Food Courts: World Premiere (Movies) Intermission (Music) and End Zone (Sports) Caribbean Beach - Old Port Royale Food Court
  • Pop Century - Everything Pop Dining
  • Port Orleans French Quarter - Sassagoula Floatworks and Food Factory
  • Port Orleans Riverside - Riverside Mill Food Court
  • Animal Kingdom Lodge: Phemora
  • Disney's Grand Floridian - Gasparilla
  • Saratoga Springs Resort - Artist's Pallete
Kosher Dining at Walt Disney World Hotels
  • Disney Resorts table service restaurants that accept reservations can serve you by calling at least 24 hours ahead.
Thank you Chabad Orlando for providing valuable information. Visit their site for even more: Chabad Orlando.   MUST READ: Tips for enjoying your visit to the park more.
  • Once inside the parks, walk left: For some reason, crowds tend to work towards the right. Walking to the left will probably mean less wait time.
  • Disney tickets: Kids under 3 don't pay to enter the parks.
  • Kid ticket price is from 3-9 years old.
  • Annual passes cost the same for adults and kids.
  • Parking costs $25 per day (Magic Kingdom).
  • Most hotels offer free shuttle service or you can take an uber.
  • Taking a train to any Disney resort will get you out of the park faster.
  • Do you have more tips? Share them below and we will add them to the list for other Kosher Travelers to benefit.
_listing_location: 1180 Seven Seas Dr, Orlando, FL 32836, USA
